comments:
Hi,

First of all: please note that this post is not related to the often-reported 
broken schema reference issue in web.xml


THE CONTEXT: a new J2EE Web application project with a simple servlet

[The long story below:]

At my place of work, I'm behind a proxy and I can't seem to configure 
Eclipse with the proxy account/password so it won't prompt me for account 
details each time the XML/WAR/whatever validator tries to connect to the 
Internet to fetch some XML schema. Therefore I usually turn all validation 
options off in Preferences->Validation dialogue.

However, IF I turn WAR validation on, and then create a J2EE1.3 or 1.4 Web 
application project, I experience weird behaviour (after creating a simple 
HelloServlet thru the wizard):

I did experience the same problems at home too (on both my home & work machines 
I am running Windows XP SP1, and Eclipse 3.1M5a + WTP1.0M3)


CONDITIONS FOR THE PROBLEM TO OCCUR:

- Need to have a J2EE Web application project open in your workspace

- The problem ALWAYS happens  when the "War validator" is turned on in the 
Preferneces->Validation dialog.

- The problem also SOMETIMES happens when the "War validator" is turned 
off in the Preferneces->Validation dialog.


DESCRIPTION & PROCEDURE TO REPRODUCE THE PROBLEM!

- Using the J2EE Explorer window, open one of your J2EE Web projects,
  and select the "webapp" node element just one row below the project title.

- double click on the Webapp node : Eclipse opens a new XML editor window 
displaying the web.xml webapp descriptor. 

- Now, close the editor, and repeat the same procedure again (double click on 
the webapp node to open the web.xml in a text editor).

This time round though, you should get one of the following errors:

1) Either a single alert box titled 'Processing Dirty Regions' and saying 
'An internal error occured during: "Processing Dirty Regions" ' . This is 
sometimes displayed 2 or 3 times consecutively.

2) Or, a series of two alert boxes is displayed: 
- First one titled 'Error' says : 'Unable to create part: ' (and then a couple 
of blank lines below in the alert box and an 'OK' button)
- Second one titled 'IWAE0052E Problems Opening Editor.', saying: 'Assertion 
failed: ' (and then a couple of blank lines again and a single 'OK' button').

What is weird with this second scenario is that after it happens, Eclipse 
sometimes will need to be restarted before it will display my web.xml file 
again, and it sometimes refuses to open other files too after that.

I did try to restart Eclipse with the -clean flag a number of times, but I 
could always reproduce the problem even after a "clean start".


Note that this problem also happens when developing the Webapp->Servlets 
or Webapp->Servlet mappings nodes in the project explorer, and then 
clicking on either a servlet, or a servlet mapping. 


And BY THE WAY, I'm not sure if this is the normal behaviour, cos when I 
double-click on a servlet I would expect the actual servlet source file 
should get displayed, *not* the deployment descriptor, but maybe this is 
just me. 
Well, I might accept the feature was actually designed to display the 
deployment descriptor when double-clicking a servlet or servlet-mapping, 
but then it would make sense I suppose to scroll to the appropriate 
section of the deployment descriptor where the servlet or the mapping is 
defined... 


Many thanks for reading, and thanks for any feedback on this,
Laurent

PS -- I include below a short excerpt of my workspace/.metadata/.log file 
pertaining to this problem. Note that the log mentions a 'FWKSample' 
project, but I'm having the problem with another project that is called 
'TestServlet24WebProject'.  

I can provide more data if needed, however my problem seems quite easy to 
reproduce so you might want to try and see  for yourself...

__________________

Hi,

I ran into the problem again, and since I'm now launching Eclipse with the -
debug and -consolelog arguments as advised by people in the eclipse.webtools 
newsgroup, I thought I would attach the console messages and give a detailed 
account of what I did and what happened:

- I launched Eclipse
- I created a new J2EE Web project using the wizard. I named it "StrutsEx1", 
selected 2.3 as Servlet API version, Apache Tomcat 5.0.28 as target server, and 
deselecte the "add module to EAR project" checkbox.
- Once the project was created, in the Project Explorer view of the J2EE 
perspective, I double-clicked on the first child item of my project 
under "Dynamic projects" [this is the item that has the name of the project and 
bears an icon with an earth globe with a label next to it showing the servlet 
version (2.3) in a box]. This caused the web.xml descriptor to open up in e new 
Eclipse text editor.
- I closed the text editor, and double-clicked again on the same item. This 
time round, it failed and came up with a dialog saying 'Unable to create 
part: '.
- All subsequent tries to open up the web.xml editor (even trying by clicking 
the web.xml file by developing WebContent/WEB-INF hierarchy) failed. I tried 
from another perspective (the JAva perspective) and it also failed.

- I then closed and restarted Eclipse, and the problem disappeared: I could now 
open up web.xml, close it, and open it again and again...


I am including the log of the first run that shows the exception trace below:

Laurent
_______

David, This looks to be a SSE issue if not please reassign with comments.

Laurent, sorry for the slow response ... but I think that assertion failed
problem (related to annotation model out of synch) has been fixed for a while
now. If you see on a recent I-build, please re-open. 

As for some of your other comments, I agree having servlet selected should at 
least give you "open with..." choice to open Java Editor or the deployment editor. 
Could you submit seperate feature request for that? jst.j2ee component, I believe.

Marking as verified as I know this issue is fixed (or correctly categorized).
If, as originator, you disagree or still see, please re-open, or open a new bug. 

Thanks very much for reporting and helping make WTP better.

This is part of a mass update to close out all stale WTP defects already verified by the reporter but awaiting closure by the assignee.  If you feel this defect was closed inappropriately, please reopen.

Thanks, John Lanuti
